JUDGES: Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP citizen who was born in DATE and is currently detained in FAC . He was represented before the Court by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

On an unspecified date in DATE the applicant was committed to ORG to serve a prison sentence . It appears that he remained there until DATE when he was transferred to ORG . On DATE he was once again detained in FAC .
On a further , unspecified date the applicant was transferred to PERSON and later to prisons in PERSON , PERSON and eventually to FAC where he currently remains .

The applicant submitted that all prisons and remand centres in which he had been detained were overcrowded . He submitted , by way of an example , that in FAC he had been placed together with CARDINAL other inmates in a prison cell measuring CARDINAL mCARDINAL . He pointed out that the ORG sanitary facilities had been old and rusty and that the walls of his cell had been covered with mould . In ORG the applicant was detained together with CARDINAL other detainees in a cell of QUANTITY . The sanitary conditions in FAC were comparable to those in FAC . In FAC the applicant was detained together with a paraplegic inmate and he submitted that he had been permanently required to take care of him , help him to wash himself and wash his clothes as well as to clean the cell , although these tasks were normally incumbent on the prison authorities .
The Government acknowledged that in FAC , in FAC and in FAC the applicant might have been

temporarily placed in cells which measured CARDINAL mCARDINAL per prisoner . They further pointed out that the cells in which the applicant had been detained were disinfected on a regular basis . Moreover , the applicant had been provided with adequate personal hygiene products and could take a bath once a week . With regard to the issue of care of the paraplegic fellow inmate , the Government explained that the applicant had never been required to take care of the detainee in question and that he had done so of his own accord , along with other co - detainees placed in the same cell . They further stated that the paraplegic detainee had been receiving adequate assistance from the prison medical staff .

More recently , the ORG also submitted that on an unspecified date , presumably in DATE , the applicant had been placed in a cell in which the statutory minimum standard of CARDINAL m² per person was respected . The applicant did not contest this submission .
On DATE and DATE the applicant filed complaints with the penitentiary authorities about the conditions of his detention . Both complaints were dismissed as unfounded .
The applicant did not bring a civil action in tort to seek compensation for the infringement of his personal rights .
( See PERSON and CARDINAL other applications v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .
